title: 111_s1643
content: The Act is titled the "Cleaner, Secure, and Affordable Thermal Energy Act" and provides a credit for converting home heating from oil fuel to natural gas or biomass feedstocks. The "Cleaner, Secure, and Affordable Thermal Energy Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for residential energy property expenditures related to qualifying heating conversions. The credit is limited to $1,500 for taxable years beginning in 2009 and 2010. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures related to qualifying heating conversions is limited to $1,500 for taxable years 2009 and 2010, and $3,500 for taxable years 2009, 2010, and 2011. No double counting is allowed for determining the credit. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures related to qualifying heating conversions is limited to $1,500 for taxable years 2009 and 2010, and $3,500 for taxable years 2009, 2010, and 2011. A qualifying heating conversion involves using qualified energy property to eliminate reliance on fuel oil for heating and removing fuel oil equipment. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures covers fuel service connection installation costs for qualified energy property used in heating conversions. Qualified energy property includes natural gas boilers, furnaces, and biomass heating appliances. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures includes biomass heating appliances like stoves, boilers, or furnaces with a thermal efficiency rating of at least 75 percent. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2010, with exceptions for qualifying heating conversions after December 31, 2011. The amendments made by this section are effective for property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2010, with exceptions for qualifying heating conversions after December 31, 2011. The amendments made by this section are effective for property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. Bonus depreciation for qualifying heating conversion property. The tax credit for residential energy property expenditures applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2010, with exceptions for qualifying heating conversions after December 31, 2011. A new subsection allows for a 50% depreciation deduction for qualifying heating conversion property in the year it is placed in service. The new subsection allows for a 50% depreciation deduction for qualifying heating conversion property placed in service before January 1, 2012. The amendment made by this section applies to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Qualified energy conservation bonds for qualifying heating conversions. Section 4 of the Act introduces amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding qualified conservation purposes, specifically focusing on reducing reliance on oil for heating systems in publicly-owned buildings through qualifying heating conversions. The amendment applies to obligations issued after the enactment of the Act. Extension of reduced depreciation period for natural gas distribution facilities from April 11, 2005, to January 1, 2013, under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Effective date aligns with Energy Tax Incentives Act of 2005.
